name: Alemtuzumab (Campath®)
indication: CLL and conditioning for Bone Marrow Transplant

required_prophylaxis.notes: Mandatory Bactrim (or equivalent) and Acyclovir/Valacyclovir due to profound T-cell depletion

supportive_care.notes: Every 15 mins during infusion due to high cytokine release risk

required_prophylaxis.notes: Prophylactic prednisone is often ordered if WBC count is >10k

supportive_care.notes: Aggressive use of emollients and lip balm for severe dryness
Do not crush or open capsules

required_prophylaxis.notes: Baseline and twice-weekly ECG to monitor QTc interval

supportive_care.notes: Maintain Potassium >4 and Magnesium >2 to prevent arrhythmias
Monitor Fibrinogen (maintain >1 g/L); Urgent CT Brain required if severe headache occurs to differentiate Hemorrhage from Cerebral Thrombosis.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Stool softeners if taking routine Ondansetron

supportive_care.notes: Rotate SubQ sites daily; cold compress may help local irritation

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Anorexia, constipation, diarrhoea, dyspepsia, stomatitis, vomiting

required_prophylaxis.notes: Acyclovir for Herpes/Shingles prevention

supportive_care.notes: Encourage fluids to prevent renal toxicity and TLS

side_effects.immune: Cytokine release syndrome, hypersensitivity, infusion reaction

premedications.timing: Mandatory before 1st dose and every dose step-up

required_prophylaxis.notes: Levetiracetam (Keppra) required during infusion due to neurotoxicity risk

supportive_care.notes: NEVER flush the line (risk of toxic bolus); maintain strict continuous rate.
ICE score/writing sample every 4-8 hours

required_prophylaxis.notes: Acyclovir/Valacyclovir mandatory to prevent Herpes Zoster reactivation
Inactivated hepatitis B vaccine mandatory to prevent hepatitis B reactivation

supportive_care.notes: Check for numbness/tingling before every dose
Monitor for hypo or hyperglycemia
Advise patient to sit on edge of bed before standing

required_prophylaxis.notes: Diarrhea is extremely common; have anti-diarrheals (Loperamide) ready

supportive_care.notes: Take with food to reduce nausea
Monitor LFTs (ALT/AST elevation is common)
Monitor ECG for QTc before and during therapy and correct serum electrolytes.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Nausea and vomiting affects 72% of patients; ensure adequate antiemetic premedication is given
Rash occurs in 67% of patients; monitor for drug eruptions or skin pigmentation changes
Diarrhea observed in 58% of patients; maintain hydration and consider antidiarrheals if needed
Infection risk is 31%; maintain strict neutropenic precautions and monitor for septic signs
Phenytoin or Levetiracetam started before and during high-dose therapy

supportive_care.notes: Monitor daily weights and bilirubin for Veno-Occlusive Disease (VOD)

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, vomiting of blood, diarrhea (watery or bloody), black/tarry stools, clay-colored stools, severe abdominal pain/cramps, mouth sores/ulcers (stomatitis), bleeding gums, loss of appetite, unpleasant breath odor, swelling of mouth

side_effects.dermatological: Rash, itching, redness/flushing, pale skin, pinpoint red spots (petechiae), unusual bleeding or bruising, yellow skin (jaundice), scaling of skin on hands/feet, painful cold sores/blisters, sweating, warm skin

side_effects.cardiovascular: Chest pain, tightness in chest, fast/pounding/irregular heartbeat, swelling of ankles/feet/legs (edema), rapid weight gain, dilated neck veins, fainting, lightheadedness on standing (orthostatic hypotension)

side_effects.respiratory: Difficult/labored breathing, rapid shallow breathing, irregular breathing, shortness of breath with exertion, cough, hoarseness, bloody nose, sneezing, sore throat

side_effects.neurological: Headache, dizziness, confusion, blurred vision, tingling of hands and feet, nervousness, pounding in the ears

side_effects.renal & urinary: Blood in urine, dark urine, decreased urine output, painful or difficult urination

side_effects.musculoskeletal: Joint pain/stiffness/swelling, lower back or side pain

side_effects.general: Fever, chills, flu-like symptoms, unusual tiredness or weakness, swollen glands, general pain or tenderness

side_effects.hepatic: Yellow eyes or skin, clay-colored stools, dark urine

premedications.timing: Often given to prevent Capillary Leak Syndrome/SIRS

supportive_care.notes: Strict I/O monitoring; avoid fluid overload but maintain hydration
Monitor palms/soles for hand-foot syndrome

name: Cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan)
indication: Leukemias (AML, ALL, CML, CLL), Lymphomas (HL, NHL, Burkitt's), MM, Breast/Lung/Ovarian/Testicular Ca, Neuroblastoma, Sarcomas, SCT Conditioning

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Nausea and vomiting are dose-related; >90% for >1.5g

side_effects.renal/urinary: Hemorrhagic cystitis (up to 40%), severe, potentially fatal

required_prophylaxis.notes: Aggressive hydration (3L/day) and frequent voiding required

supportive_care.notes: Strict I/O monitoring; encourage voiding before bed to empty bladder

name: Cytarabine (Ara-C / Cytosar®)
indication: AML, ALL, CML, NHL, HL, MDS

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Nausea and vomiting are dose-related; >90% for >1.5g, peritonitis

side_effects.renal/urinary: Hemorrhagic cystitis (up to 40%), severe, potentially fatal

premedications.timing: Begin 6-12h before High-Dose (HiDAC) and continue 24h after

required_prophylaxis.notes: Perform signature/writing test before every high dose

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for 'Cytarabine Syndrome' (fever, rash, bone pain) 6-12h post-dose

premedications.timing: Consider starting 2-3 days prior to therapy in patients with high tumor burden (to prevent TLS)

required_prophylaxis.notes: Baseline ECHO/MUGA required due to lifetime cumulative dose toxicity

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for pleural effusion (dry cough, shortness of breath)
Do NOT administer with Proton Pump Inhibitors (needs acid for absorption)

name: Daunorubicin (Cerubidine®)
indication: Leukemias (AML, ALL, CML), Lymphomas (HL, NHL), Sarcomas (Ewing's, Kaposi's, Rhabdo), Wilm's Tumor

side_effects.cardiovascular: Congestive heart failure (rare, dose related), cardiomyopathy (rare, dose related)

required_prophylaxis.notes: Strict contraception required; teratogenic risk (fetal abnormalities, abortion, and growth restriction observed in animal studies)
Baseline ECHO/MUGA required due to lifetime cumulative dose toxicity

supportive_care.notes: COLD PACKS only. Dexrazoxane if available.
Counsel on risk of gonadal suppression (amenorrhea, azoospermia, testicular atrophy)
Breastfeeding is not recommended due to potential secretion into breast milk
Monitor for secondary malignancies (leukemias reported with topoisomerase II inhibitors)
Warn patient urine will turn red/orange for 24-48 hours

side_effects.hematological: Unusual bleeding or bruising; pinpoint red spots (petechiae); pale skin (anemia)

side_effects.hemorrhage: Black, tarry stools; bleeding gums; blood in urine or stools; bleeding after defecation

side_effects.cardiovascular: Chest pain; fast or irregular heartbeat; dizziness/fainting on standing (orthostatic hypotension)

side_effects.pulmonary: Cough; difficult/fast breathing; pink frothy sputum (pulmonary edema); congestion; hoarseness

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Nausea; vomiting; stomach pain/bloating; sores/ulcers in mouth (stomatitis); loss of appetite

side_effects.skin: Hives; itching; rash; redness/pain at catheter site; yellow skin (jaundice); flushed skin

side_effects.lymphatics/edema: Swelling of the face, hands, ankles, or feet (edema); swollen lymph glands

side_effects.musculoskeletal: Body aches; muscle pain, cramps, or spasms; weakness/heaviness of legs

side_effects.neurological: Headache; seizures; drowsiness; numbness/tingling (neuropathy); mood changes; blurred vision

side_effects.renal/urinary: Difficult or painful urination; frequent or increased urination; bloody or cloudy urine

side_effects.metabolic: Increased thirst; increased hunger; fruit-like breath odor (hyperglycemia symptoms)

side_effects.constitutional: Fever; chills; unusual tiredness or weakness; unexplained weight loss

required_prophylaxis.notes: Strict contraception required. Females: during + 6 months after last dose. Males: during + 3 months after last dose. Risk of birth defects.
Regular blood tests required to monitor for leukopenia (infection risk) and thrombocytopenia (bleeding risk).

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for bruising/bleeding (melena, hematuria). Use soft toothbrush; avoid razors, contact sports, and dental work without clearance.
Avoid sick contacts. Report fever, chills, cough, or painful urination immediately.
Counsel patients on risk of infertility (specifically male infertility reported).
Nausea/vomiting is common; ensure adequate antiemetic coverage.

name: Dexamethasone (Decadron®/Dexasone®)
indication: Multiple Myeloma, ALL, Lymphoma, Brain Tumor, Anti-emetic prophylaxis and Hypersensitivity reactions

required_prophylaxis.notes: H2 blockers (Famotidine) or PPIs (Omeprazole) often required to prevent ulcers
Required if on high-dose protocol for >4 weeks (e.g., Bactrim)

supportive_care.notes: Monitor blood glucose Q6H; insulin sliding scale may be needed even in non-diabetics
Directly cytotoxic to lymphocytes; monitor uric acid/electrolytes upon initiation
Administer in the morning to reduce risk of steroid-induced insomnia

name: Doxorubicin (Adriamycin®)
indication: Leukemias (ALL, AML), MM, Lymphomas (HL, NHL), Breast, Bladder, Lung, Gastric, Hepatic, Thyroid, H&N, Testicular, Gyn Ca, Sarcomas (Osteo, Ewing's, Soft Tissue, Kaposi's), Neuroblastoma, Wilm's Tumor

required_prophylaxis.notes: Track lifetime cumulative dose; Baseline ECHO required

supportive_care.notes: High risk of severe mucositis; encourage ice chips (cryotherapy) during infusion
COLD PACKS only.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Hormonal birth control may be less effective; use backup method (e.g., condoms) during and for 2 months after last dose (men and women).
Prophylactic medication may be required to prevent Tumor Lysis Syndrome; monitor fluid status and uric acid.

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for fever/dyspnea; risk is highest in first 2-3 months
Monitor bilirubin; drug can interfere with testing, causing false elevation
Teratogenic risk; pregnancy test required before starting treatment.
Avoid OTC medicines and herbal supplements unless approved by doctor.
Monitor for rapidly rising WBC count

name: Etoposide (VP-16, Vepesid®)
indication: Leukemias (AML, ALL), Lymphoma, MM, Lung (SCLC, NSCLC), Testicular/Germ Cell, Ovarian, Breast, Prostate, H&N, Brain/Ependymoma, Adrenocortical, Neuroendocrine, Merkel Cell, Thymoma, Sarcomas (Ewing's, Kaposi's, Rhabdo), Wilms' Tumor, Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Anorexia, constipation, diarrhea, mucositis, nausea and vomiting, stomatitis, taste alteration

required_prophylaxis.notes: Etoposide may cause fetal harm/teratogenicity. Effective contraception is recommended during treatment and for 6 months after the last dose (for both males and females).

supportive_care.notes: Monitor BP frequently; rapid infusion causes hypotension
Check for precipitation (crystals) in tubing/bag
Risk of reduced spermatogenesis and ovarian/testicular atrophy. Consider sperm banking and genetic consultation prior to treatment.
Breastfeeding is not recommended; drug is excreted in human milk.
Monitor for secondary malignancies (e.g., leukemia) and chromosomal abnormalities associated with epipodophyllotoxins.

name: Fludarabine (Fludara®)
indication: CLL, AML, NHL, Conditioning for BMT and Waldenström Macroglobulinemia

required_prophylaxis.notes: Mandatory Acyclovir (Herpes) and Bactrim (PCP) due to T-cell depletion
Irradiated blood products ONLY (prevents TA-GvHD)
Irradiated blood products are mandatory to prevent fatal transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GVHD).
Screen all lymphoma patients for Hepatitis B (HBV) reactivation prior to therapy.
Teratogenic risk; effective contraception required during treatment and for 6 months after cessation (for both men and women).

supportive_care.notes: Severe CNS toxicity (blindness, coma, seizures) associated with high doses; monitor neurological status closely.
Monitor renal function; dose reduction required for renal impairment and geriatric patients to prevent toxicity.
Monitor for hemolytic anemia (contraindicated in decompensated hemolytic anemia).
Monitor for new onset skin cancer and secondary leukemias (AML/MDS).

required_prophylaxis.notes: Premedicate with a corticosteroid, antihistamine, and acetaminophen prior to each dose to prevent anaphylaxis.
Consider leukoreduction to <30,000/mm3 before treatment to prevent fatal Tumor Lysis Syndrome and renal failure.
Females: Use effective contraception during and for 7 months after last dose. Males: Use for 4 months after last dose.

supportive_care.notes: Protect IV bag from light during administration
Monitor for Veno-occlusive disease (VOD) or sinusoidal obstruction syndrome, which can be fatal.
Monitor ECG and electrolytes for risk of QT prolongation, especially in patients with known risk factors.
Animal studies show reduced spermatogenesis and ovarian/uterine atrophy; counsel on reproductive risks.
Breastfeeding is not recommended during treatment and for at least one month following the last dose.
Embryo-fetal toxicity and morphological abnormalities reported; inform patients of teratogenic risk.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Females: Use effective contraception during and for 6 months after last dose. Males: Use for 4 months after last dose.
Correct hypokalemia and/or hypomagnesemia prior to treatment to minimize QT prolongation risk.

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for rapid weight gain, fever, dyspnea
Watch for PRES (headache, seizures, vision loss)
Monitor ECG and electrolytes for risk of QT prolongation, especially in patients with known risk factors.
Animal studies show testicular toxicity (degeneration/necrosis of germ cells); counsel on reproductive risks.
Breastfeeding is not recommended due to potential secretion into breast milk.
Teratogenic risk; embryo-fetal death and skeletal/visceral abnormalities reported in animal studies.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Monitor EKG for QTc prolongation
Strict contraception required for both men and women during treatment and for at least 30 days after the last dose due to birth defect risk.
Pregnancy test required within 7 days prior to starting treatment.

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for muscle spasms; magnesium supplementation may be needed
Monitor for dysgeusia (taste changes) and weight loss
Monitor for changes in heart rhythm (QT prolongation); report dizziness or uneven heartbeat immediately.
Do not donate blood, blood products, or sperm during treatment and for 30 days after the last dose.
Counsel patients on risk of male infertility.
Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea are common; ensure adequate symptom control.
Do not take OTC medicines or herbal supplements without physician approval.

name: Hydroxyurea (Hydrea®)
indication: CML, AML, Myeloproliferative disorders, Melanoma, Ovarian, Head and neck, Cervical, Uterine, NSCLC

required_prophylaxis.notes: Allopurinol and hydration if WBC is high
FDA Pregnancy Category D: Positive evidence of human fetal risk. Strict contraception required.

supportive_care.notes: Chemo gloves required for handling capsules
Check ankles for painful leg ulcers
Avoid combination with antiretrovirals (didanosine/stavudine) due to risk of pancreatitis, hepatotoxicity, and peripheral neuropathy.
Contraindicated in men contemplating fatherhood.
Breastfeeding is not recommended due to secretion into breast milk.
Monitor bone marrow function; adjustment required for patients with prior chemotherapy or marked marrow depression.

name: Ibrutinib (Imbruvica®)
indication: CLL, NHL, Mantle cell lymphoma, Waldenström macroglobulinemia

side_effects.hematological: Anemia, febrile neutropenia, leukocytosis, lymphocytosis, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia

side_effects.infection: Hepatitis B reactivation, infections, pneumonia, sepsis

required_prophylaxis.notes: Hepatitis B reactivation reported; screen all patients for HBV and consider prophylaxis per protocol.
Effective contraception recommended during treatment and for 3 months after treatment (unknown if present in semen; animal teratogenicity).

supportive_care.notes: Hold 3-7 days before any surgery/procedure
Monitor for new onset Atrial Fibrillation
Hyperuricemia and TLS reported; monitor uric acid and electrolytes.
Monitor for secondary malignancies and skin cancer.
Breastfeeding is not recommended due to potential secretion into breast milk.

side_effects.gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain, anorexia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting

side_effects.general_disorders: Extravasation hazard, fever, tissue necrosis after extravasation

required_prophylaxis.notes: Verify NO history of hypersensitivity to idarubicin, anthracyclines, or anthracenediones.
Verify Total Bilirubin is ≤86 micromol/L (Contraindicated if >86).
Baseline ECG and ECHO or MUGA required. Adhere to maximum cumulative doses.
Required during treatment and for at least 6.5 months after last dose (Teratogenic/Embryotoxic).
Required during treatment and for at least 3.4 months after last dose (Genotoxic/Sperm damage).
Do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least 14 days after last dose.

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for severe diarrhea/mucositis
COLD PACKS only.
Closer LVEF monitoring for patients >60, or with prior cardiac disease/radiation (Risk of asymptomatic decline).
Monitor for increased suppression if radiation occurred within 2-3 weeks prior.
Counsel patients (male and female) on preservation prior to treatment due to reproductive toxicity.
Monitor for secondary leukemias (1-3 year latency), especially if combined with DNA-damaging agents.

name: Ifosfamide (Ifex®)
indication: ALL L3 variant, Burkitt’s lymphoma, CLL, Lymphoma (HL, NHL), Bladder cancer, Brain tumours, Breast cancer, Cervical cancer, Ewing’s sarcoma, Gastric cancer, Germ cell tumours (gonadal, extra-gonadal, non-seminomous, testicular, ovarian), Pancreatic cancer, Lung cancer, Osteosarcoma, Peripheral neuroectodermal tumour, Rhabdomyosarcoma, Soft tissue sarcoma

premedications.timing: Mandatory concurrent infusion (often mixed in same bag)

required_prophylaxis.notes: Mesna and aggressive hydration are mandatory to prevent bladder toxicity
Monitor for confusion/hallucinations (Ifosfamide-induced encephalopathy)
Mandatory use of a uroprotective agent such as mesna.
Maintain daily fluid intake of at least 2 liters; correct electrolyte imbalances and urinary obstructions prior to treatment.
Verify absence of severe leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, renal/hepatic impairment, cystitis, urinary obstruction, active infection, or advanced cerebral arteriosclerosis.
Delay treatment for at least 10 to 14 days after surgery to avoid impaired wound healing; do not administer within three months of unilateral nephrectomy.
Adequate contraception recommended for both sexes due to mutagenic potential; discontinue breastfeeding prior to therapy.

supportive_care.notes: Methylene Blue should be available on the ward for severe neurotoxicity
Strict I/O monitoring; maintain high urine output
Close monitoring required for patients with prior radiation, nephrotoxic drug use, or children ≤5 years (risk of Fanconi’s syndrome).
Administer fast-acting diuretics (e.g., furosemide) if urinary excretion is insufficient.
Use caution in patients with bone marrow infiltration, brain metastases, impaired hepatic function, or abnormal serum albumin.
Counsel on potential gonadal suppression, including amenorrhea or azoospermia.

name: Imatinib (Gleevec®)
indication: CML, Ph+ ALL, Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GIST)

side_effects.hepatic: elevated bilirubin, elevated ALT, AST, alkaline phosphatase

required_prophylaxis.notes: Verify no history of hypersensitivity to imatinib; confirm negative pregnancy status via serum or urine test prior to initiation.
Screen for Hepatitis B virus (HBV) in chronic carriers and implement prophylaxis per protocol to prevent reactivation.
Mandatory contraception during treatment due to risk of spontaneous abortions and congenital anomalies; breastfeeding is not recommended.

supportive_care.notes: Take with a large meal and full glass of water to reduce GI upset
Monitor for periorbital edema and weight gain
Monitor renal function prior to treatment and periodically thereafter to manage potential progressive loss of function.
Counsel male patients regarding potential risks of oligospermia and impaired spermatogenesis.
Maintain awareness of clastogenic potential and animal data showing carcinoma at high doses, though clinical trials show no significant increase in secondary malignancies.

side_effects.respiratory: cough, differentiation syndrome, dyspnea, pleural effusion

required_prophylaxis.notes: Mandatory premedication with a corticosteroid, antihistamine, and antipyretic prior to each dose.
Consider prophylactic anti-infectives; perform cytoreduction prior to treatment in patients with high peripheral lymphoblast counts to prevent tumor lysis syndrome.
Monitor ECG and electrolytes for QT/PR interval prolongation; use caution in patients with history of rhythm disturbances or AV block.
Confirm negative pregnancy status prior to treatment; avoid live vaccines within 2 weeks prior to, during, and until B-cell recovery after treatment.

supportive_care.notes: Monitor for venoocclusive disease, especially in patients >65, those with liver disease, or those receiving HSCT conditioning with two alkylants.
Females: Use contraception during and for 8 months after last dose; wait 2 months after last dose to breastfeed. Males: Use contraception during and for 5 months after last dose.
Continuous testing and surveillance for potentially fatal infections.
Counsel on risks of gonadal/testicular atrophy and hypospermia observed in animal studies.

name: Ivosidenib (Tibsovo®)
indication: IDH1-mutated AML, MDS, Biliary tract cancer

required_prophylaxis.notes: Monitor ECG and correct electrolytes prior to treatment; contraindicated in congenital long QT syndrome.
Verify negative pregnancy status prior to treatment; non-hormonal contraception is mandatory due to potential drug interactions with hormonal methods.

supportive_care.notes: High risk (14%); monitor for respiratory distress and start steroids immediately if suspected
Avoid high-fat meals (increases concentration)
Dose reductions may be necessary for patients on concomitant medications involving the CYP 3A4 pathway.
Patients of childbearing potential should use contraception during treatment and for 1 month after the last dose; women should not breastfeed for 1 month after final dose.
Counsel on animal data showing reversible uterine atrophy and testicular degeneration.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Aspirin or Enoxaparin/Warfarin is mandatory due to high DVT risk
Pregnancy testing/counseling required for dispensing

supportive_care.notes: Weekly counts for first 8 weeks (Neutropenia risk)
Do NOT donate blood or semen during treatment and for 4 weeks after stopping.
Ensure optimal control and monitor for hypo- or hyperthyroidism, especially in patients with a history of thyroid disease.
Monitor for signs of acute solid organ transplant rejection.
Close observation for patients >65 years due to significantly higher incidence of serious side effects (60% vs 35%) and higher discontinuation rates.
Monitor digoxin levels periodically; lenalidomide may increase maximum digoxin concentration by 14%.
No significant effect on warfarin noted, though standard monitoring for thalidomide analogues is prudent.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Strongly recommended before starting therapy; homozygous deficient patients require alternative therapy or a 10-fold dose reduction.
Mandatory mercaptopurine dose reduction to 25-33% of the standard dose if given concomitantly due to xanthine oxidase inhibition.
Confirm negative pregnancy status (Category D); contraception required for both sexes during and for 6 months after treatment. Breastfeeding is contraindicated.

supportive_care.notes: Take on empty stomach (1h before or 2h after food)
Do NOT take with milk or dairy  or consider separating milk consumption by 6-8 hours to avoid drug inactivation (Xanthine oxidase interaction)
Monitor liver function regularly; frequency of injury increases when doses exceed 2.5 mg/kg/day.
Maintain daily urine output of at least 2 liters (adults) or 2 L/m²/day (pediatrics) and alkaline urine to prevent xanthine calculi.
Avoid cow's milk at the time of administration; consider separating milk consumption by 6-8 hours to avoid drug inactivation by xanthine oxidase.
Monitor closely when using aminosalicylates (mesalamine, sulfasalazine), methotrexate, or nondepolarizing muscle relaxants.

required_prophylaxis.notes: Sodium Bicarbonate fluids to keep Urine pH >8
Leucovorin must be started exactly on time

supportive_care.notes: Avoid NSAIDs, Penicillins, and PPIs (delay clearance)

premedications.timing: Prophylactic use often needed (high nausea rate)

supportive_care.notes: Take with food to prevent severe nausea
Assess for new cough/dyspnea (Interstitial Lung Disease)

required_prophylaxis.notes: Baseline LVEF (ECHO/MUGA) required. Cumulative dose toxicity applies.

supportive_care.notes: Urine, whites of eyes (sclera), and skin may turn BLUE-GREEN for 24–48 hours
Stop immediately. Apply COLD packs. Monitor for tissue necrosis.
Strict tracking required (Max usually 140 mg/m²); higher risk if patient previously had Doxorubicin

required_prophylaxis.notes: Baseline and ongoing neurological assessment required (Somnolence/Confusion)

supportive_care.notes: Aggressive IV fluids recommended to prevent renal failure
High risk of ataxia/dizziness; assistance required for ambulation

required_prophylaxis.notes: Baseline and periodic ECG due to Black Box Warning for QT prolongation

supportive_care.notes: Strict fasting: NO FOOD 2 hours before and 1 hour after dose
Correct hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia aggressively

required_prophylaxis.notes: Screen for Hepatitis B; initiate antivirals if surface antigen positive
Antihyperuricemics (Allopurinol) and hydration for high tumor burden

supportive_care.notes: First dose split over 2 days; withhold antihypertensives 12h prior

required_prophylaxis.notes: Aspirin or Enoxaparin/Warfarin required
Mandatory pregnancy testing and counseling

supportive_care.notes: Weekly counts during initial cycles due to neutropenia risk

required_prophylaxis.notes: Monitor for arterial thrombosis (MI/Stroke/Peripheral occlusion)

supportive_care.notes: Monitor lipase and amylase levels every 2 weeks
Monitor hepatic function tests monthly

required_prophylaxis.notes: Take with food or milk to minimize GI irritation
Monitor for fungal infections (Thrush) during prolonged courses

supportive_care.notes: Taste is very bitter; mix liquid with sweet vehicle (chocolate syrup) for pediatric compliance
Watch for 'Steroid Rage', anxiety, or depression
Do not stop abruptly after long courses; must follow taper schedule to prevent adrenal insufficiency

required_prophylaxis.notes: ECG prior to initiation and weekly during induction (Black Box Warning)
Maintain Potassium > 4.0 and Magnesium > 2.0

supportive_care.notes: Avoid strong CYP3A inhibitors (e.g., Azole antifungals) or reduce dose
Monitor for fever, dyspnea, and weight gain

required_prophylaxis.notes: Antiviral prophylaxis if surface antigen or core antibody positive

supportive_care.notes: Highest risk during first infusion; titrate rate slowly

required_prophylaxis.notes: Use urea-based creams to prevent Hand-Foot Skin Reaction (HFSR)

supportive_care.notes: Hold drug prior to major surgery
Monitor for ischemia or infarction

required_prophylaxis.notes: Aspirin or anticoagulation required
Strict birth defect prevention program

supportive_care.notes: Administer at bedtime to manage drowsiness
Monitor for peripheral neuropathy (numbness/tingling)

premedications.timing: Start 2-3 days prior to first dose

required_prophylaxis.notes: CRITICAL: Follow 5-week 'Ramp-Up' dosing strictly. Hydration >1.5L/day.

supportive_care.notes: Avoid grapefruit, Seville oranges, and starfruit (CYP3A4 inhibitors)
Check chemistry 6-8h and 24h after first dose and every dose increase

required_prophylaxis.notes: NEVER administer intrathecally – Fatal if given via spinal route

supportive_care.notes: WARM COMPRESSES ONLY. Hyaluronidase if available.
Monitor for constipation and peripheral neuropathy (though less neurotoxic than Vincristine)

premedications.timing: Prophylactic use recommended to prevent ileus

required_prophylaxis.notes: NEVER administer intrathecally. Dispense in minibags if possible.

supportive_care.notes: WARM COMPRESSES ONLY. Hyaluronidase if available.
Monitor for constipation, foot drop, and jaw pain
